Award.AwardTitle: FW-HTF-RL: Learning systems that enable healthcare workers to perfect safety-critical hospital work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This project develops new technology to assist healthcare workers, thereby making healthcare<br/>safer and more cost-effective. Healthcare is 18% of the Gross Domestic Product, yet errors annually<br/>lead to as many as 250,000 deaths and more than $500 billion in costs. The project is creating<br/>virtual assistants in intensive care and surgical units, which guide nurses and other healthcare<br/>workers, using worker input and experimental results to guide technology development. These<br/>virtual assistants give step-by-step guidance and feedback during complex tasks and monitor<br/>routine activities to make sure no steps are missed. Benefits include assistance in learning new<br/>activities, reducing stress, detecting possible problems, and automating some of the work providers<br/>do now to document their ongoing activities.<br/><br/>The research team is developing prototypes, experimental results, and effectiveness<br/>measurements in healthcare settings for virtual assistants, called “ambient intelligent monitors”<br/>(AIMs). The team includes computer scientists, electrical engineers, clinicians, behavioral<br/>scientists, and healthcare economists at Stanford hospitals, Intermountain hospitals, and<br/>Stanford’s Schools of Engineering, Business, and Medicine. Research goals include developing<br/>sensors, computing, and software for AIMs, discovering how clinical workers prefer to<br/>communicate with AIMs, and experimenting with work environments to maximize their value to<br/>patients, families, and clinicians. The project includes three cycles of research, covering hand<br/>hygiene, Intensive Care Unit care bundles, and laparoscopic surgery. Each cycle includes analysis,<br/>design, development, implementation in normal hospital care, and evaluation. The research is<br/>proceeding along four parallel tracks. One track is designed to develop hardware for capturing privacy-protected<br/>data on edge devices such as cameras, depth sensors, and microphones. A second<br/>track is for developing algorithms that discern success and failure in enacting intended clinician<br/>bedside activity. A third track is for obtaining healthcare worker input to develop preferred ways<br/>for AIMs to interact with people, such as providing verbal prompts, confirming observations<br/>made by sensors, and automatically updating medical records. A fourth track is for running<br/>experiments to measure the clinical, behavioral, operational, and economic impacts of the AIMs.<br/>By coupling the engineering research with real-world deployment and clinical studies, this research<br/>will create new knowledge that is unattainable in a purely technology-driven or purely<br/>observational investigation.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
